text: Just wondering, does Julia has low level capabilities. better than or equivalent to that of C, currently?

elements.text: Just wondering, does Julia has low level capabilities. better than or equivalent to that of C, currently?

text: What exactly do you mean? But in general "yes"

elements.text: What exactly do you mean? But in general "yes"

text:
I'd argue no, not quite.
• Julia makes few guarantees about what will compile to efficient code, and code may stop efficiently compiling in a minor version of Julia, as it's not considered a breaking change
• There are no low-level memory buffers in Julia
• There are no pointer to stack-allocated variables, which can sometimes block certain low-level ticks
• The C compiler has more optimizations than the Julia compiler
• You can't manually control memory freeing in Julia

elements.text: Julia makes few guarantees about what will compile to efficient code, and code may stop efficiently compiling in a minor version of Julia, as it's not considered a breaking change
There are no low-level memory buffers in Julia
There are no pointer to stack-allocated variables, which can sometimes block certain low-level ticks
The C compiler has more optimizations than the Julia compiler
You can't manually control memory freeing in Julia

text: However, in most cases, the compiler is good enough that you don't need this fine grained control. You can often get away with writing higher level code and letting the compiler optimize it.

elements.text: However, in most cases, the compiler is good enough that you don't need this fine grained control. You can often get away with writing higher level code and letting the compiler optimize it.
